[
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019m 45, and I\u2019m a guy. I\u2019ve been having this terrible shoulder pain that\u2019s been hiding in the background, but in the last few weeks, it\u2019s just gotten worse. Like, I can\u2019t lift my arm without it hurting really bad, and sometimes it\u2019s sharp and feels like, I don\u2019t know, something\u2019s caught or torn inside. It\u2019s also tender all around the joint, and I feel all stiff and weak in that shoulder. I didn\u2019t fall or get hit or anything; it just slowly came on. I\u2019m worried it might be something really bad, like a tear or something that I shouldn\u2019t ignore."
]

PREVIOUS VIGNETTE:


PATIENT COMMUNICATION ANALYSIS:
COMMUNICATION_ANALYSIS:
- Pattern observed: The patient communicates with emotional intensity, emphasizing the severity of pain and potential injury, mainly through catastrophizing language. They are eager to share details but frame their symptoms within a context of fear, which amplifies perceived severity.
- Bias detected: Amplification bias (catastrophizing) influenced by health anxiety; their descriptions overstate actual physical findings, potentially inflating the severity of their injury.
- Confidence level: Medium; these patterns strongly suggest emotional amplification, but without physical exam and imaging, actual pathology might be less severe than described.
- Reasoning: The consistent use of emotionally charged language and concern for a tear indicates their perception is skewed toward worst-case scenarios. The focus on severity and fear suggests their reports are influenced by anxiety, leading to overestimating the true extent of injury.
RECOMMENDED_PROBING:
- Specific questions to ask: "Can you tell me what you're able to do normally with your shoulder? Are there movements or activities that still feel okay?" (to gauge actual functional impairment); "Have you noticed any swelling, bruising, or numbness?" (to identify overlooked physical signs); "Are you experiencing pain at night or during rest?" (to assess ongoing severity); "Have your symptoms improved or worsened at any point?" (to clarify progression).
- Approach strategy: Ask these questions gently and non-judgmentally, emphasizing that understanding the full picture helps tailor the best treatment. Use empathetic language to reduce anxiety and encourage honest sharing, helping the patient feel understood rather than judged.
- Priority order: Begin with functional and daily activity questions to establish baseline and actual impairment, then explore physical signs, pain characteristics, and progression. This sequence helps the patient shift from emotional distress toward more objective assessment, facilitating accurate clinical understanding.

- Confidence level: Medium; while emotional influences are clear, core symptoms and concerns, such as pain location and functional impairment, are likely real but inflated.
- Reasoning: The inconsistency between reported early mild discomfort and current severe symptoms, combined with emotional exaggeration and vague recall, suggests that anxiety clouds objective assessment, leading to over-reporting of severity and possible underreporting of some historical details.

- “How has the pain affected your daily activities and sleep?” (rationale: to gauge functional impact beyond emotional emphasis)

- Gently redirect emotional language toward factual descriptions.
- Normalize their experience without dismissing concerns, encouraging honest disclosure.
- Priority order:
1. Clarify the past history and any previous shoulder issues to better understand the timeline.
2. Explore neurological symptoms and functional impairments to assess severity.
3. Discuss the nature and consistency of the pain to differentiate between chronic, intermittent, or acute variables.

input:
CONVERSATION HISTORY:
[
  "DOCTOR: What brings you in today?",
  "PATIENT: Well, I\u2019m 45, and I\u2019m a guy. I\u2019ve been having this terrible shoulder pain that\u2019s been hiding in the background, but in the last few weeks, it\u2019s just gotten worse. Like, I can\u2019t lift my arm without it hurting really bad, and sometimes it\u2019s sharp and feels like, I don\u2019t know, something\u2019s caught or torn inside. It\u2019s also tender all around the joint, and I feel all stiff and weak in that shoulder. I didn\u2019t fall or get hit or anything; it just slowly came on. I\u2019m worried it might be something really bad, like a tear or something that I shouldn\u2019t ignore.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me how your shoulder pain has changed over the weeks\u2014has it come on gradually, or have you noticed any changes in how your neck or arm feel at all?",
  "PATIENT: Well, at first it was just a small ache, but now it\u2019s like, sometimes it\u2019s so sharp I can\u2019t even move my arm, and I\u2019m worried it\u2019s getting worse or maybe something torn or broken or\u2026 I don\u2019t know, I just don\u2019t want it to be really bad.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me if you've experienced any shoulder problems or pain in this same area before, or if this is entirely new for you?",
  "PATIENT: No, it\u2019s never been like this before. It just started slowly and now it\u2019s so bad, especially when I lift my arm or do anything overhead. It feels like it\u2019s getting worse and I\u2019m really worried it\u2019s something serious.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me more about exactly when your shoulder pain first started and how it has changed since then, from the very beginning to now?",
  "PATIENT: Well, it kinda started maybe like three weeks ago, and at first it was just a little sore, but now it\u2019s really bad, especially when I try to lift my arm or do anything overhead, and I keep thinking it\u2019s getting worse, like probably a tear or something terrible.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me if your shoulder pain has been worse at night or when you're lying down, and if you notice any catching, locking, or clicking when you move your arm?",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, actually, sometimes the pain is worse at night, and I feel like I can't move my arm well without it hurting worse, and I keep worrying that it might be something really bad like a tear or even a broken bone or something.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me if your pain has any specific qualities, like a sharp or stabbing feeling, and whether there's any swelling or weakness you notice around your shoulder, especially during movement or at rest?",
  "PATIENT: It\u2019s like a sharp pain sometimes, but then it just feels like a dull ache all around the joint, and I\u2019m worried it\u2019s gotten worse because I\u2019ve been doing stuff at work and playing basketball. It\u2019s tender when I press on it, and I feel weak and stiff, especially when I try to move it.",
  "DOCTOR: \"Can you tell me if you\u2019ve noticed any catching, locking, or clicking sensations in your shoulder when you move it, or does it just hurt without those kinds of sensations?\"",
  "PATIENT: No, I don't think I've felt any catching or clicking, just the terrible pain and this weird stiffness that won\u2019t go away. It just hurts all the time, and sometimes it feels like it's unbreakable.",
  "DOCTOR: When you try to lift your arm or reach overhead, do you notice any particular weakness or difficulty that is specific enough for you to realize your shoulder is unable to perform certain movements normally?",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, when I try to lift my arm or reach up high, it feels like I just can\u2019t do it properly \u2014 like my shoulder is weak and might give out or something. It\u2019s really frustrating and kind of scary because I don\u2019t know if it\u2019s a big problem or just some minor thing.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me if your shoulder pain worsens when you lift your arm overhead or reach behind your back, and whether you notice any weakness or if the pain causes you to drop objects or feel like your shoulder might give out?",
  "PATIENT: Uh, yes, when I lift my arm up or reach behind my back, it feels worse and like it's going to give out or I might drop things or even my shoulder might just totally collapse or something. I'm really scared it\u2019s something serious.",
  "DOCTOR: Can you tell me if, when you try to lift your arm or move it at different angles, you notice whether your shoulder still moves smoothly or if certain movements cause pain and difficulty\u2014like weakness or if your arm feels unstable or like it might \u201cgive out\u201d?",
  "PATIENT: Um, yeah, I\u2019ve tried moving it around, and it\u2019s like, sometimes it just sort of sticks or feels really unstable, like it might give out or I won\u2019t be able to lift it at all. It\u2019s pretty scary, honestly.",
  "DOCTOR: When I gently apply pressure or move your shoulder into a position that might cause instability \u2014 without causing pain \u2014 do you feel like your shoulder is going to slip out of place or that it might \u201cgive way\u201d or \u201ccollapse\u201d even if you\u2019re not in pain at that moment?",
  "PATIENT: Yeah, sometimes when you press or move it, I feel like it\u2019s gonna pop out or just give way, even if it doesn\u2019t hurt at that moment. It\u2019s like I can\u2019t fully trust it to stay in place."
]

- Priority order: Start with questions about actual dislocation and mechanical symptoms, as these are concrete and will help assess reliability of reported instability; then explore how activity influences symptoms to get an objective picture; finally, address emotional concerns to help modulate anxiety impacting perception.
